tier_1_determinative.five_or_more_persons_committing_dacoity: The case involves a complaint filed under Section 395 of IPC, indicating the involvement of five or more persons in committing or attempting to commit dacoity.

tier_2_material.property_stolen: Ornaments and other articles, mostly belonging to the customers of the appellant's jewellery shop, were stolen.

tier_3_contextual.incident_location: The incident occurred at the house of the appellant and complainant, Smt. Lalita Kothari.
tier_3_contextual.incident_date_time: The complaint was filed on 1st April 1998, indicating the incident occurred prior to this date.

tier_4_procedural.case_title: Ashok Kundanmal Kothari vs. The State of Maharashtra
tier_4_procedural.court_name: High Court of Judicature at Bombay
tier_4_procedural.counsel_for_appellant: Mr. R.U. Singh, Advocate for Appellant
tier_4_procedural.counsel_for_respondent: Mr. B.H. Mehta, A.P.P. for State
tier_4_procedural.sections_invoked: IPC Sections 395, 452, 341, 397 and Sections 25 and 27 of the Arms Act.
tier_4_procedural.acts_and_sections: Indian Penal Code Sections 395, 452, 341, 397; Arms Act Sections 25, 27.

residual_details.additional_facts: Some accused persons were arrested and some property was recovered at their instance. The accused persons were acquitted. The appellant's application for the return of property was initially allowed by the Magistrate but retained by the Sessions Judge due to absconding accused. The property was eventually ordered to be returned to the appellant upon furnishing a bond.
